paragraphs.text: Rejected by your parents? Remember: you are not alone.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: In the light of the sad case of Leelah Alcorn, the Ohio transgender teenager who killed herself after being forced to undergo conversion therapy, I have been asked how teenagers can deal with parents who are completely unsupportive or hostile to their emerging independent identity
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: You don't choose your parents
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: You are at their mercy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They control your environment
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: to a great extent, they are your environment
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: You don't have the power to control your own resources: your own money, or even your own food
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: When you were a baby you had even less autonomy
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: for you to develop you had to do so in relationship with them
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: How you think, feel, move and speak is created with your parents
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: Even more importantly, how you learn to soothe yourself in the face of pain or upset is in large part down to how they soothed you when you were growing up
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As you develop, more influences affect who and what you are and allow different parts of you to grow
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: You go to school, meet more people and hear more ideas
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: you begin to experience urges and feelings in yourself that may not be recognised by your parents
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: or even anyone else you know
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: But these days, we have the internet
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: so
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: there is usually someone out there who can understand to some extent how you feel
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: All of us have a need to have our internal selves mirrored by the people around us
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It's unlikely that anyone finds themselves always completely understood by relying on how others respond to them
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: we all have a need to seek this type of connection - especially if we don't find anything approaching it at home
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Not being understood by our parents is one thing
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: what if a teenager feels persecuted for not being exactly like their family or peers?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What if he or she is persecuted, abused, put through exorcisms or so-called conversion therapies?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Some people who survived time in concentration camps told of the importance of holding on to their imagination and their minds
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: when you are being abused by your parents that is harder to do
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: because we have a need to believe that our parents good
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Otherwise
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: we rationalise, how can we be safe?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So the unconscious process that tends to happen is that we start to blame ourselves for how we feel instead
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Often young people don't think of waiting it out until they can flee
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: because time seems to pass more slowly as a teenager
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: so
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: there can be a real danger of teenage suicide
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Despite the terrible feelings of rejection a teenager might experience, one day they may be able to understand their parents' point of view
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they are strict and inflexible - unable to move with the times or accept anything other than their values
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: this is probably the result of trauma: either their own trauma or transgenerational trauma- trauma passed on to them by their parents
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: When we are not traumatised, we can live fluidly in the present, responding to situations as they arise
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: when traumatised, people stick to strict rules and codes, as though living in emergency mode
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they are fearful of deviating from these
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: when they see their children being very different from them, they panic
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In their belief system, to deviate from the rule book is to be cast out
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: to be cast out is to be unsafe, and possibly to die
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They are worried because they cannot imagine accepting you as you want to be, cannot imagine that it would be possible for you to be accepted anywhere
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They may even fear that because you are different, they will no longer be accepted by their community
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The main emotion holding this system together is shame and the fear of feeling shame
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Shame feels like an annihilation
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the teenager can sense some of this
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it may help them to take the persecution they get from their parents less personally
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Because it is unhelpful to see one party as good and the other as bad
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Everyone needs to be listened to
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: What advice would I give to the teenager who is rejected or tormented by their parents for their beliefs, identity or sexuality?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Find a sympathetic witness for what you are going through
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: a friend, a teacher, a school counsellor - someone whose idea of you actually reflects who you feel you really are
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: You can then hold on to their image of you when times are tough
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And most importantly, although it feels like a lifetime, it isn't
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: You will be able to walk away one day and build a new network consisting of mutual support around you
paragraphs.label: assumption
